comments.commentBody: And, can you imagine, he ran for President!  We had him on TV and everything!  Proof positive that there are segments of the U.S. population that can't tell reality from fantasy.  Sometimes I wonder if democracy hasn't gone too far. Sad to say.

".... Had I not had those services available to me, I would not be standing where I am today.”

That's it! The key to the whole oil tycoon, neo-con puzzle. They don't want Davis or Collins or anyone with common sense and a sense of humanity to be standing in the Texas senate or any other place that might hinder their quest for obscene wealth, religious and social domination. Once one sees through the flimsy construction of Rick Perry's empty, ten-gallon hat, one can imagine his "keep em down on the farm" mentality. There's not much more to him and his brood.
For a Cardinal fan, Joe, I thought your clue was an act of unmitigated class.
Just exactly the same for me.  Pinto instead of paint.  That and spending 5 minutes figuring out oolite and deterge.  But I liked it!

Thanks to Howie, this is the first time I've had even a clue as to the identity of John's Mystery Guest. (And it helps that the photo is now bigger. When did that happen?)

Personally, I would have guessed "Spock's older brother."

Okay, I guess I'll take Howie's word for it. Although if the word is HOSTLRRA I have no idea how to pronounce it.

But I'd never have recognized him after an interim of something close to 60 years.

DLD, "HOSTLRRA" stands for "Hi O Silver, the Lone Ranger Rides Again!"
Sorry it didn't come to you Tonto! Heh Heh Heh

As for WWW, of course that's an acronym for Wild Wild West

Oh, The Depps that Howie will sink to
Here is the definition of Krozel: SHARING A BED after eating DRIED APRICOTS.

Not only HEARING AIDS and PINTO, but also CURLING before HUILING What was I thinking?

That's what I get for looking at the word instead of the clue.

Friday took me nine minutes, and I did Saturday’s in seven.

Of course, I can also hit my 5 iron 235 yards.

(It’s amazing what the Internet has done for my skill sets.)

I don't think you serve your argument well by not knowing very much about Texas. The state votes Democratic in its urban areas, where Obama won in 2012. I returned to Austin after 40 years on the East Coast, and I was struck by the public civility, spectacular skies, and delish tacos. I drive everyday past limestone cliffs and swaths of scrub oaks; in the spring the wildflowers carpet the roadsides so thickly that you have to gather yourself to pay attention to the driving. In truth there are deep traditions of populism here --  we saw them emerge at Tuesday's filibuster, the young students, the old lady liberals, the pony-tailed men, the bright-eyed geeks, the earnest social activists and public health experts and dark-haired hispanics -- a Capitol's bounty of bright, interested folks. As elsewhere in American, politics in Texas have been contorted and corrupted by the usual suspects -- too much "bidness" money, galloping religious beliefs -- but the pundits are not merely puffing when they talk about Texas going purple and blue. You can see it in how quickly people here have responded to the leadership of Wendy Davis and Kirk Watson and Leticia Van de Putte and others. These are the leaders that Texans are at last owed and deserve.

I don't know about you, but I voted for Obama twice because he was better (from my blue-collar American POV) than the Republican alternatives. He's not a very good president, but think how bad McCain or Romney would have been for families with less than $5 million in assets, which was McCain's famous estimate of what it took to be "middle class" in (Republican) America.

Like many ofther naive Obama apologists Peter writes at 12:42 pm on 6/28 that after 1964 LBJ had a  2/3 majority  in the House and Senate.  But what Peter fails to report is that many of the 2/3 were segregationists who were just as  instransigent as the Tea Party extremists.  But LBJ had the plitical experience and skills to beat up enough of them to pass the most  sweeping civil rights laws in our history.  Obama doesn't fight, he doesn't even know where the ring is.   Regardless of race, creed, color or sexual orientation, please don't ever elect an amateur again, even if he or she is pretty and wows the media..

The Raza movement in Texas needs to wake up and register voters and get out the vote the way black communities do in Mississippi or Alabama. Elect a Democratic Governor and Lieut. governor, and the session would be a lot more fun. How about a Castro for the Senate to oppose Cornyn, another Castro for L Gov. And Davis for Governor?
If voting is made mandatory, we need a "None of the Above" button also...
Bravo!  Let's hope these great thrashings are the last hope of the delusionals.

Texas, as has been so often stated, is ruled by white men (and some women) who live in the 19th century, when women knew that their place was in the home and left the running of society to the males.  That is inevitably going to change -- history is not on Perry's side, thank God; and Wendy Davis may have provided, finally, a rallying point for the future of that benighted state. What a courageous and intelligent woman -- there are many more, both male and female, who will eventually drag the imams in ten-gallon hats into the current century.  Patriarchy is really the same all over the world, and it is going to go into the wastebin of history -- not without vicious fighting, but it will go. The foolish, blustering Rick Perry belongs to the past; Davis is the future.
"They Might Be Giants" is a great film with George C. Scott.
I wonder what that LETTER C stands for.?
Curmudgeon?

It'll be many hours before I try my hand at Saturday's puzzle, but I just gotta post a video for Leapy, after reading her late post on Friday's blog. They Might Be Giants appear for the second day in a row, with "Ana Ng":

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7dQLkxz6c2E

Dr. S. Jeevananda Reddy: You don't say which graph you are criticizing in which sentence. Let's take http://www.skepticalscience.com/going-down-the-up-escalator-part-1.html
The graph alternates between "how skeptics view GW" and "How realists view GW". You have to watch it long enough to see it change back and forth on the same data.

Do people go to Bath to DETERGE?

-- Manchester = Top Footballers

Hand up for that, Jane.

Loved the Saturday, gave up on the Friday. Life is too short, and there are too many other puzzles online, to go back to that one.

There are actually many different types of Service Dogs these days, each one more wonderful than the last. It's just a shame not to be able to pet them, they're so beautiful with their ever-attentive facial expressions!

So Dr. S. Jeevananda Reddy denies GW. Southern India will remain wet while northern India will dry out per "Drought Under Global Warming: a Review" by Aiguo Dai
http://www.atmos.albany.edu/facstaff/adai/
But India will get too hot for people to live outdoors.

What Dr. S. Jeevananda Reddy should do: Make sure as many people in India as possible, at least a billion, see the movie "Pandora's Promise." The article above talks in positive terms about fossil fuels. I have heard that there have been protests against nuclear power in India. India is vulnerable to GW.

There were really only two health outcome measured: there was "no significant effect of Medicaid coverage on the prevalence or diagnosis of hypertension or high cholesterol levels or on the use of medication for these conditions."
Average blood pressure was within the normal range to begin with and stayed there. The effect on diabetes is mildly disappointing but it's still relatively short term. To say Medicaid has no effect isn't accurate.

I think this author badly fails to understand the statistics. The bigger question of this study is why there seems to be so little health behavior benefit to having Medicaid. The dramatically larger and frightening issue is that Oregon has a lower socioeconomic group that somehow does not benefit "statistically significantly" in the measures studied from having health insurance coverage. Why do some of us fail to lose weight, fail to control salt intake, fail to adjust diet for diabetes control?
I did not see a comparison to how these two lower socioeconomic population groups compared to middle and upper income groups in ability to make the behavior changes important to improving health status. Isn't that the bigger question?
Little-known fact: the US declared war on Japan in 1941, but not on Germany. Germany declared war on the US on December 21st.

I will respect the thoughts of those who have commented and are Jewish, but I ask them to keep in mind one thing.

If you ever forget that you are Jewish, the world will be there to remind you.

Larry, no, I do not think that 68 years is enough time for some people to get over it.  I do think that you feel that way; you didn't see your newborn tossed in the air for target practice.  But then again, if you did, you 'would have gotten over it'

i dont think that it is enough .... because the most of german still think the same way, and didnt recognise that the other nations are humans just like them. i am saying that after a long expeeiance living in germany till they made me leave the country... just watch the germn news  !!!!!
No, one should always remember and "never forget". But: the continuous hatred does no good and this should be overcome.

Some of the commentators here wear their continuing hatred of all things German on their sleeves, as if a badge of honor.

Just like the Sunni and Shia do, like Serbs and Croats, like...well, you can fill in your own blanks.

Sixty-eight years is time enough to get over it, don't you think?
Has the younger generation ever dared to talk to their parents about their peers?

Brecht's poem in concept is not so different from the actual German National Anthem.
But to under stand that you have to know the difference between
"Deutschland ueber alle", and
"Deutschland ueber alles".
A huge difference

MOST of us Americans are horrified at the virtual annihilation of our indigenous population in earlier centuries.
Really? Have a poll?

My father, who was also a Holocaust survivor, told me not to buy German. To this day I try to honor his request because, unfortunately, he is not around anymore to say otherwise. I will not ask the same from my children but I have no choice. Poor me - I am driving Jaguar and Lexus.

"it is clear that African-Americans are justified in their continuing resentment of their past treatment by Americans...."

But they are not justified in any way in resenting white me because of their past treatment. Or, for that matter, any white person who had nothing to do with it.

European Americans murdered, easily, without remorse, casually, millions upon millions of African Americans. About 12 million Africans departed for America, about 2 million died en route, before even setting foot on land. Millions died from disease, overwork, and despair throughout the country, and so many millions more in the fetid cane fields of the lower South in the early 19th century. So, altogether, what? 10 million? 15 million? Probably twice that.

My people, the Irish, who came here a century ago, had no part. But they didn't hesitate for one second to feast on wealth generated by three centuries of slavery. By golly, we white folks pulled ourselves up by our own bootstraps; African slaves made the boots, and African American labor, in the last 150 years, made the bootstraps. No wonder the slave owners kept guns by their beds.

I think "resent" doesn't quite cover being called lazy, dependent, on and on, while seeing the fruits of slavery so casually appropriated. The Jews in Europe? Maybe slightly different case, but not so much.

So, no, I'm not buying German stuff. There is collective guilt, at least economically. They destroyed, they owe. That much we can measure. And what about me? Do I owe? Sure.

.

Many commenters self-righteously express the opinion that continued avoidance of German products by Jews or descendents of holocaust victims is unjustified or hateful. We need look no further than the experience of African-Americans in our own country to understand why such behavior is quite justifiable. African-Americans have endured centuries of slavery, bigotry, lynchings, discrimination and, even now, denial of rights in America and the United States. While I am categorically opposed to every one of these and support equal rights for all Americans, it is not difficult to understand why African-Americans, young and old, may be unable to overlook what has been done to them and their ancestors. The history of their horrific treatment and ongoing discrimination at the hands of white Americans would seem to warrant their suspicions and anger for generations to come. Although I personally have not been a party to such discrimination, just as young Germans are not responsible for what was perpetrated by the Nazis, it is clear that African-Americans are justified in their continuing resentment of their past treatment by Americans, just as Jews are towards Germany for the crimes of the Holocaust. May we all learn to treat each other with dignity and respect.
I love the prom photo --those folks look very cool and posied.  tres chic ( even circa 1970s)
Here's a thought for you.  Maybe Reagan actually believed in what he stood for as President.
